questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable predictor of a difficult airway during preoperative assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mallampati classification
Explanation:
Mallampati classification evaluates the visibility of the oropharyngeal structures when the patient opens their mouth and protrudes the tongue. A higher Mallampati score (Class III or IV) correlates well with difficult intubation. While other factors like inter-incisor and thyromental distances are also important, Mallampati is the most widely used and reliable single predictor in clinical practice.

choices.text: Stop smoking the day before surgery
Stop smoking at least 24 hours before surgery
Stop smoking at least 2 weeks before surgery
Stop smoking at least 8 weeks before surgery

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker is scheduled for elective surgery. The best advice regarding cessation of smoking to reduce postoperative pulmonary complications is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Stop smoking at least 8 weeks before surgery
Explanation:
Smoking increases the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications due to airway irritation, increased mucus production, and impaired mucociliary clearance. Evidence shows that cessation for at least 8 weeks before surgery significantly reduces these risks. Shorter durations may not confer the same benefit and can even transiently worsen secretions and airway reactivity.

questions.text: Which of the following preoperative medications is most appropriate to reduce the risk of aspiration pneumonitis in a patient undergoing general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metoclopramide
Explanation:
Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent that increases lower esophageal sphincter tone and promotes gastric emptying, reducing the risk of regurgitation and aspiration. It is often used in combination with H₂ blockers or proton pump inhibitors as part of aspiration prophylaxis in patients at risk (e.g., full stomach, diabetic gastroparesis).

choices.text: It is a definitive airway and protects against aspiration
It is contraindicated in spontaneously breathing patients
It can be used as a rescue device in difficult airway situations

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 It can be used as a rescue device in difficult airway situations
Explanation:
LMA is a supraglottic airway device that does not provide full protection against aspiration, but is easy to insert without laryngoscopy and is very useful as a rescue airway when intubation or mask ventilation fails. It is especially important in the difficult airway algorithm and is suitable for spontaneously breathing or ventilated patients under anesthesia.

choices.text: Reposition the head and ensure a tight mask seal

questions.text: During mask ventilation with a bag-valve-mask (Ambu bag), you notice inadequate chest rise and increasing resistance. Which of the following is the first step in troubleshooting the issue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Reposition the head and ensure a tight mask seal
Explanation:
The most common cause of poor bag-mask ventilation is inadequate head positioning and mask seal. The head tilt-chin lift or jaw thrust along with a good seal usually improves ventilation. Airway adjuncts (like nasopharyngeal airways) or more invasive steps (like intubation) should only be considered after basic maneuvers have failed.

choices.text: Deep anesthesia with risk of awareness
Patient is awake or very lightly sedated
The patient is in a surgical plane of anesthesia

questions.text: In a patient under general anesthesia, the Bispectral Index (BIS) monitor reads 95. This indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Patient is awake or very lightly sedated
Explanation:
The BIS monitor provides a numerical value (0–100) representing the level of consciousness based on processed EEG.
• BIS 40–60: Adequate general anesthesia
• BIS >80–100: Awake or very light sedation
Thus, a BIS of 95 suggests the patient is almost fully awake, and deepening of anesthesia is likely required.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is not measured by pulse oximetry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PaO₂
Explanation:
Pulse oximetry estimates SpO₂, heart rate, and provides a plethysmographic waveform, but does not measure PaO₂ directly. PaO₂ is obtained from arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis. Remember: SpO₂ and PaO₂ are related but not equivalent.

questions.text: A sudden drop in end-tidal CO₂ (ETCO₂) to near zero in a patient under general anesthesia is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Disconnection of the breathing circuit
Explanation:
A sudden and complete drop in ETCO₂ usually points to a mechanical issue such as:
• Circuit disconnection
• Extubation
• Complete airway obstruction
Gradual fall = hypoperfusion or embolism. Sudden = mechanical error.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common intraoperative arrhythmia detected by ECG monitoring under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Premature ventricular contractions (PVCs)
Explanation:
PVCs are common during anesthesia, often due to:
• Hypoxia
• Hypercarbia
• Electrolyte imbalance
• Halogenated agents (e.g., isoflurane)
Occasional PVCs may not be significant, but frequent or polymorphic PVCs require attention.

questions.text: In capnography, which phase of the capnogram corresponds to alveolar co2 levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Phase III – Alveolar plateau
Explanation:
• Phase I: Dead space gas (no CO₂)
• Phase II: Mixture of dead space and alveolar gas
• Phase III: Alveolar plateau — represents CO₂ from alveoli; used to calculate ETCO₂
• Phase IV: Inspiration, sharp downstroke back to baseline
Any changes in Phase III (slope or height) help diagnose ventilation or perfusion issues.

questions.text: Which of the following IV induction agents is most likely to cause adrenal suppression even after a single dose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Etomidate
Explanation:
Etomidate inhibits 11β-hydroxylase, a key enzyme in cortisol synthesis. Even a single dose can suppress adrenal steroidogenesis for up to 24 hours, making it less ideal in septic or critically ill patients. However, it has the advantage of cardiovascular stability, which makes it useful in hemodynamically unstable patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is a notable side effect of propofol during induction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bradycardia and hypotension
Explanation:
Propofol causes vasodilation and myocardial depression, leading to hypotension and bradycardia, especially in elderly or hypovolemic patients. It reduces intracranial pressure and is anti-emetic, making it favorable for neuroanesthesia and day-care surgeries.

questions.text: Which IV induction agent is most appropriate in a patient with severe bronchial asthma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Ketamine
Explanation:
Ketamine is a bronchodilator and preserves spontaneous respiration, making it the agent of choice in asthmatics or in patients with reactive airway disease. It also maintains cardiovascular stability by increasing sympathetic tone — though caution is needed in patients with CAD or hypertension.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of thiopentone as an induction agent is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

GABA-A receptor agonism
Explanation:
Thiopentone, like most induction agents (except ketamine), acts via GABA-A receptor agonism, enhancing chloride influx into neurons, causing hyperpolarization and CNS depression. Ketamine is an NMDA antagonist, making its mechanism unique.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a property of ketamine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decrease in blood pressure
Explanation:
Ketamine increases blood pressure and heart rate due to sympathomimetic action. It provides excellent analgesia and causes dissociative anesthesia by interrupting thalamocortical pathways. However, due to cerebral vasodilation, it can increase ICP, making it relatively contraindicated in patients with raised intracranial pressure.

choices.text: It is a competitive antagonist at nicotinic receptors
It causes bradycardia on first dose and tachycardia on repeat doses
It is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase
It is safe in patients with hyperkalemia

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding succinylcholine (scoline)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase
Explanation:
Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that acts as an agonist at nicotinic receptors, causing continuous depolarization. It is rapidly metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase.
• It causes tachycardia on the first dose and bradycardia with repeat dosing, especially in children.
• It is contraindicated in hyperkalemia due to risk of potassium release from depolarized muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following non-depolarizing muscle relaxants is steroid-based and undergoes hepatic metabolism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vecuronium
Explanation:
Vecuronium is a steroid-based non-depolarizing muscle relaxant metabolized hepatically and excreted by liver and kidney.
• Atracurium and Cisatracurium undergo Hofmann elimination (organ-independent) and are preferred in renal/liver failure.
• Rocuronium is also steroid based but more commonly used for rapid sequence induction & shows no metabolism in body.

questions.text: Which of the following is a selective reversal agent for steroidal non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like rocuronium and vecuronium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sugammadex
Explanation:
Sugammadex is a modified cyclodextrin that encapsulates steroidal NDMRs like rocuronium and vecuronium, rapidly reversing their action without affecting acetylcholinesterase.
• Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor, used for all NDMRs, but less specific and requires anticholinergic co-administration (e.g., atropine/glycopyrrolate) to block muscarinic side effects.

questions.text: In Train-of-Four (TOF) monitoring, a TOF ratio of <0.9 at recovery indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Residual neuromuscular blockade
Explanation:
TOF monitoring involves 4 stimuli at 2 Hz per second. The TOF ratio (T4/T1) is used to assess recovery:
• TOF ratio ≥ 0.9: Indicates adequate recovery for safe extubation.
• TOF ratio < 0.9: Indicates residual paralysis, which may lead to hypoventilation, airway obstruction, or aspiration.
• Fade pattern is typical of NDMRs (not seen with depolarizers).

choices.text: It releases histamine and may cause hypotension
It is a steroid-based muscle relaxant
It is not suitable in renal failure

questions.text: Which statement is correct about atracurium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It releases histamine and may cause hypotension
Explanation:
Atracurium is a benzylisoquinolinium NDMR, broken down via Hofmann elimination and ester hydrolysis, making it suitable in renal and hepatic failure.
However, it can cause histamine release, leading to flushing, bronchospasm, or hypotension. Its safer alternative is cisatracurium, which does not cause histamine release.

questions.text: The rate of induction with an inhaled anesthetic agent is inversely proportional to which of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Blood:Gas partition coefficient
Explanation:
A lower blood:gas partition coefficient means the agent is less soluble in blood, so it saturates the blood quickly and achieves faster induction and recovery.
• Agents like Desflurane and Sevoflurane have low blood solubility and thus rapid onset.
• Halothane has a high blood:gas coefficient, leading to slower induction.

questions.text: Which of the following inhaled anesthetic agents is most likely to cause hepatic toxicity on repeated exposure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Halothane
Explanation:
Halothane is metabolized by the liver (up to 20%) and associated with halothane hepatitis, especially in females and after multiple exposures.
Modern agents like Sevoflurane and Desflurane have minimal metabolism and are much safer for the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following combinations correctly matches the volatile anesthetic agent with its unique adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Nitrous oxide – megaloblastic anemia
Explanation:
Nitrous oxide inactivates vitamin B12 by oxidizing cobalt in methylcobalamin, inhibiting methionine synthase, leading to megaloblastic anemia and neuropathy on prolonged exposure.
• Sevoflurane can cause compound A-related nephrotoxicity in low-flow settings.
• Desflurane may cause airway irritation, not nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following volatile agents is least suitable for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its pungency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Desflurane
Explanation:
Desflurane is pungent and irritating, causing coughing, breath-holding, and laryngospasm during inhalational induction.
• Sevoflurane is non-pungent, has a pleasant odor, and is ideal for pediatric induction.
• Halothane was previously used for kids but is now avoided due to cardiac sensitization.

choices.text: Mapleson A is best for spontaneous ventilation
Mapleson D is most efficient for spontaneous breathing
Mapleson B is the most commonly used in pediatric anesthesia
Mapleson C has the lowest fresh gas flow requirement for controlled ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Mapleson breathing systems used in anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mapleson A is best for spontaneous ventilation
Explanation:
• Mapleson A (Magill system) is most efficient for spontaneous ventilation (FGF ≈ minute ventilation).
• Mapleson D (e.g., Bain's circuit) is preferred for controlled ventilation.
• Mapleson F (Jackson Rees modification) is popular in pediatrics.
• Mapleson B and C are inefficient and rarely used.

choices.text: Head-down tilt and suctioning of oropharynx

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of aspiration pneumonitis during induction of anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Head-down tilt and suctioning of oropharynx
Explanation:
In suspected aspiration, the immediate goal is to prevent further pulmonary contamination:
• Place the patient in a Trendelenburg (head-down) and lateral position.
• Suction the oropharynx and trachea.
• Bronchoscopy is considered only for large solid particles.
• Routine antibiotics/steroids are not indicated unless infection or wheezing/bronchospasm develops.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male undergoing surgery under general anesthesia develops hypercarbia, muscle rigidity, and rising temperature. What is the definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Dantrolene
Explanation:
The scenario is classic for malignant hyperthermia (MH), triggered by agents like succinylcholine and volatile anesthetics.
• Dantrolene is a ryanodine receptor antagonist that inhibits calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, reversing the hypermetabolic state.
• Supportive measures include cooling, managing hyperkalemia, and correcting acidosis.

choices.text: Posterior fossa craniotomy in sitting position

questions.text: Which surgical procedure is most commonly associated with venous air embolism (VAE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior fossa craniotomy in sitting position
Explanation:
Venous air embolism occurs when atmospheric air enters the venous circulation, typically when the surgical field is above the level of the heart, such as in:
• Neurosurgery in sitting position (especially posterior fossa and cervical spine).
• Detection is by TEE or precordial Doppler.
• Management includes flooding the field, lowering the head, and aspirating air via a central line.

questions.text: A patient develops foot drop following surgery done in lithotomy position under general anesthesia. The most likely cause is injury to which nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Common peroneal nerve
Explanation:
Foot drop is typically due to common peroneal nerve injury, which winds around the head of the fibula.
• In lithotomy position, pressure from the leg supports against the fibular head can compress the nerve.
• Proper padding and positioning are essential to prevent such nerve injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a known risk factor for postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Age > 65 years
Explanation:
Younger age is actually a risk factor; age > 65 is associated with lower incidence of PONV.
Other risk factors include:
• Female gender
• Non-smoker
• History of motion sickness or prior PONV
• Use of volatile anesthetics and opioids

choices.text: Infection increases protein binding of local anesthetics
Infection causes acidic pH that ionizes local anesthetics

questions.text: Which of the following best explains why infection at the injection site decreases the efficacy of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Infection causes acidic pH that ionizes local anesthetics
Explanation:
Local anesthetics are weak bases. In acidic environments (like infected tissue), more of the drug exists in the ionized form, which cannot cross lipid membranes to reach the intracellular sodium channels.
Thus, onset is delayed and efficacy is reduced in infected tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics is an amide and is metabolized in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bupivacaine
Explanation:
• Amide local anesthetics (e.g., Lidocaine, Bupivacaine, Mepivacaine) are hepatically metabolized.
• Ester local anesthetics (e.g., Procaine, Benzocaine, Tetracaine) are metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase.
Remember the rule:
Amides have "i" in the name twice, while esters only once (e.g., Lidocaine, Bupivacaine vs. Procaine).

questions.text: A patient receiving a peripheral nerve block with Bupivacaine suddenly develops seizures, followed by hypotension and bradycardia. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 20% lipid emulsion therapy
Explanation:
This is a classic presentation of Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST), especially with Bupivacaine (cardiotoxic).
• 20% lipid emulsion therapy acts as a "lipid sink", pulling lipophilic anesthetics out of tissues (including the heart and CNS).
• Seizures may be controlled with benzodiazepines.
• Avoid propofol in CV collapse due to its myocardial depressant effect.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics is known for having the fastest onset of action when used for infiltration anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lidocaine
Explanation:
Lidocaine has:
• Moderate lipid solubility
• Low pKa (≈7.9), so more of it is in the non-ionized form at body pH
→ Leading to rapid onset and moderate duration.
Bupivacaine has slower onset but longer duration.

questions.text: Regarding the local anesthetic agents, which of the following is correctly matched with its property or use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bupivacaine – high cardiotoxic potential
Explanation:
• Bupivacaine is well known for high cardiac toxicity, particularly ventricular arrhythmias and arrest.
• Lidocaine can safely be combined with epinephrine to prolong its effect and reduce systemic absorption.
• Mepivacaine is not preferred for IVRA (Bier’s block); Lidocaine without adrenaline is safer.
• Articaine has shorter duration due to its ester component and is often used in dental anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates spinal anesthesia from epidural anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Site of injection
Explanation:
• Spinal anesthesia involves injection into the subarachnoid space (CSF-filled).
• Epidural anesthesia is administered into the epidural space, which is outside the dura mater.
• Both techniques can use similar drugs and adjuvants, and both carry a risk of hypotension due to sympathetic blockade, but the site of injection is the fundamental differentiator.

questions.text: A child is undergoing infraumbilical surgery. Which regional block is most appropriate and commonly used for both anesthesia & post operative analgesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Caudal block
Explanation:
• Caudal anesthesia is a type of epidural block commonly used in children for lower abdominal, perineal, and lower limb surgeries.
• It is safe, technically easier in children due to anatomic landmarks, and can be used in combination with general anesthesia.

questions.text: During a spinal block at L3-L4, which of the following sensations is lost first?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Temperature
Explanation:
• Sensory block by local anesthetics follows the order:
Sympathetic > Temperature > Pain > Touch > Proprioception > Motor
• This is due to differential sensitivity of nerve fibers: small myelinated fibers (e.g., Aδ, C) are blocked earlier than large ones.

questions.text: Which approach is not commonly used for a brachial plexus block?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Transforaminal
Explanation:
• The transforaminal approach is not used for brachial plexus blocks.
• The common approaches for blocking the brachial plexus are:
o Interscalene (proximal upper limb, shoulder)
o Supraclavicular (entire upper limb)
o Infraclavicular and axillary (distal limb procedures)

choices.text: Epidural block has a faster onset
Epidural block uses lower drug volume
Epidural block always provides a higher level of anesthesia

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding epidural anesthesia compared to spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Epidural catheter allows repeated dosing
Explanation:
• An epidural catheter enables continuous or repeated administration, making it ideal for labor analgesia and prolonged surgeries.
• Compared to spinal anesthesia:
o Onset is slower
o Requires higher volume and concentration of drug
o The level achieved depends on dose, volume, and patient position

questions.text: Which oxygen delivery device can provide a fixed and precise fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Venturi mask
Explanation:
• The Venturi mask uses color-coded adapters to entrain a precise and fixed FiO2 (e.g., 24%, 28%, 35%, 40%, or 60%).
• Nasal cannula and simple face masks deliver variable FiO2 depending on the patient's breathing pattern.
• Non-rebreather masks can deliver high FiO2 but not as precisely as Venturi masks.

choices.text: Excessive secretions and inability to protect airway

questions.text: Which of the following is a major contraindication for initiating non-invasive ventilation (NIV)?
questions.solution:
A. MoCorrect Answer (C)

Excessive secretions and inability to protect airway
Explanation:
• NIV is contraindicated in patients who cannot protect their airway or have excessive secretions due to the risk of aspiration.
• It is effective in COPD exacerbations, cardiogenic pulmonary edema, and moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure.

choices.text: Delivers low FiO2 with variable flow rates
Provides heated and humidified oxygen at high flow rates to reduce dead space and improve oxygenation
Replaces the need for mechanical ventilation in all respiratory failure cases
Causes significant patient discomfort due to dry air delivery

questions.text: High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) therapy provides which of the following physiological benefits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Provides heated and humidified oxygen at high flow rates to reduce dead space and improve oxygenation
Explanation:
• HFNC delivers heated, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min), which helps wash out anatomical dead space, improve oxygenation, and reduce work of breathing.
• It is comfortable and better tolerated than standard oxygen devices.
• HFNC does not replace mechanical ventilation in all cases but can delay or avoid intubation in selected patients.

questions.text: Which mechanical ventilation mode allows spontaneous breathing but provides a mandatory breath if the patient fails to initiate one within a set time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SIMV (Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation)
Explanation:
• In SIMV, the ventilator delivers a preset number of mandatory breaths synchronized with the patient’s effort.
• The patient can breathe spontaneously between mandatory breaths without ventilator assistance.
• A/C mode delivers a mandatory breath with every patient effort or backup if none occurs.

questions.text: What is the most important clinical criterion to assess readiness for weaning from mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adequate oxygenation (PaO2/FiO2 ratio > 150-200)
Explanation:
• Adequate oxygenation is crucial for weaning success.
• Other parameters include stable hemodynamics, ability to initiate spontaneous breaths, acceptable acid-base status, and mental status.
• Sedation and age are important but not sole determinants.

choices.text: Early defibrillation → Early recognition → Early CPR → Advanced care → Post-resuscitation care
Early recognition → Early CPR → Early defibrillation → Advanced care → Post-resuscitation care
Early CPR → Early defibrillation → Early recognition → Advanced care → Post-resuscitation care
Early recognition → Early defibrillation → Early CPR → Advanced care → Post-resuscitation care

questions.text: Which of the following correctly lists the steps in the ‘Chain of Survival’ for cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Early recognition → Early CPR → Early defibrillation → Advanced care → Post-resuscitation care
Explanation:
The Chain of Survival comprises five critical links:
1. Early recognition and activation of emergency response
2. Early CPR to maintain circulation
3. Early defibrillation to restore normal rhythm
4. Advanced resuscitation care by healthcare providers
5. Post-resuscitation care to optimize recovery

choices.text: Provide chest compressions at a rate of 50-70 per minute
Allow complete chest recoil after each compression
Interrupt compressions every 5 seconds to check pulse
Use excessive ventilation to ensure oxygen delivery

questions.text: Which of the following is a key “do” when performing high-quality CPR by a Basic Life Support (BLS) provider?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Allow complete chest recoil after each compression
Explanation:
High-quality CPR includes:
• Chest compressions at a rate of 100–120 per minute
• Depth of compressions about 5-6 cm in adults
• Allow complete chest recoil between compressions for effective venous return
• Minimize interruptions to compressions
• Avoid excessive ventilation

choices.text: Call for help → Open airway → Provide rescue breaths
Call for help → Start chest compressions → Open airway → Provide rescue breaths
Call for help → Start chest compressions → Attach AED → Provide rescue breaths
Call for help → Open airway → Start chest compressions → Provide rescue breaths

questions.text: In the Adult Basic Life Support (BLS) algorithm, what is the correct sequence of actions after confirming unresponsiveness and no normal breathing but pulse present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Call for help → Open airway → Provide rescue breaths
Explanation:
The Adult BLS algorithm:
• Check responsiveness 
• Call for help/emergency services
• Check for pulse & breathing, not more than 10 seconds.
• If pulse present but no breathing, open airway and give rescue breaths at 1 every 6 seconds ( 10 breaths per min)

choices.text: Epinephrine should be administered every 10 minutes during cardiac arrest
Defibrillation is indicated immediately for asystole
Amiodarone is used for shockable rhythms refractory to defibrillation
Atropine is the first drug for pulseless electrical activity (PEA)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amiodarone is used for shockable rhythms refractory to defibrillation
Explanation:
• Epinephrine is given every 3-5 minutes during cardiac arrest.
• Asystole is not shockable; defibrillation is for VF/pulseless VT.
• Amiodarone is used after failed defibrillation attempts in VF/pulseless VT.
• Atropine is no longer recommended for PEA or asystole.

choices.text: Encourage the patient to cough forcefully

questions.text: In a clinical scenario where an adult is choking due to complete airway obstruction and unable to cough or speak, what is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich maneuver)
Explanation:
• In complete airway obstruction, the patient cannot breathe, talk, or cough effectively.
• The next step is to perform abdominal thrusts to expel the foreign body.
• If the patient becomes unresponsive, begin CPR and call for emergency help.
